comments.commentBody: My daughter and I knew Ladis for one week in 1985. At the beginning of the Reagan/Gorbachev detente, we traveled with Jane to Russia on a PSU art history tour. Ladis accompanied us. He had such remarkable passion, certainty and belief in humanity if only we would just attend to it. At the airport leaving for Finland he saw a propaganda poster (in Russian) that angered him. He ripped it down, wadded it up and threw it on the floor. We entered the plane and waited and waited. Finally, armed soldiers came aboard (we were sure for Ladis!), removed another passenger and we flew safely, more appreciatively home never knowing what the poster was about. We will never forget your Dad! How fortunate to know him for even a week. Our sympathy to you and your Mother.

I always read Mr. Kristoff's pieces.  Now we see the source of his intelligence and perception! His father could well have been a bitter, complaining old man but instead used his experiences, even suffering, to keep going to make the world a better place.  Here's to heroes such as he!

Thanks for sharing from your heart.  My father was also an immigrant born in the Austro-Hungarian Empire in 1898, in what is now Slovenia.  He spoke/read a dozen languages and was a college professor.  Like you, I was an only child, and both of my parents poured their love into me, which I am passing on to future generations of my children and my students. Dad died in 1988 and I miss him still, especially at joyful family occasions.  My condolences to you and your family.  Be gentle with yourselves at this time of grief and continue to pass on the blessings you received.
I can't think of a greater gift than what your father left to you and to the world in his poignant statement. Thank you for sharing his inspiring story and the contents of your heart, Mr, Kristof.
So very, very sorry for your loss.  Your father sounds as if he was a remarkable man -- and he leaves you a wonderful legacy.

What a wonderful column. Mr. Kristof, while you may have never spoken the words you wish you had, your life has surely shown your father how well you have taken his words to heart. And as the old saying goes, "actions speak louder than words". I lost my dad nearly ten years ago, and I still miss him, even though our shared faith tells me I will see him again.
On a less formal note, the photo of your father shows a man whom I am sure it was a pleasure to know!

Mr. Kristof, Your column touched me deeply and I have printed a copy to save.  My son is the grandson of Greek and Russian immigrants; they are all gone now and the further away we get from them the more I want remind him about the relatives "before him". People like your father who prevailed over so much and then came to America, an unknown for them, and made a rich life for themselves and their families. We're very lucky. Thanks for reminding me again
Nicholas, just wanted to say how sorry I am that you lost your dad. He sounds like he was a wonderful man and father.

There are very few things, if any at all, that a man would desire for.

A great respect from their children and the ability to overcome obstacles that to many I hardly understandable.

Like your father I came to this country, became a professor at a Ivy League University and I firmly believe that was the support from my family and from my parents who never attended even a high school that make us strong.

Yourself represented by your columns suggest a very kind person. What a pride for a father as well.

To both of you (albeit a little late) I wish a very happy father's day.
I'm sorry for your loss--and mine; my father died last year, an octogenarian.  We will not see the like of their generation again.

I can't add much to the eloquent posts from other readers.  I do want to say thank you for sharing the beautiful story of your father.  Someone told me when my mother died that I would never get over it, but I would learn to live with it.  I've found that to be true.
Thank you sir for sharing a wonderful father with us. Inspired me and my children. A must read for all the children of the world...inspiring them  towards a more peaceful humanistic world!!!!

Bless you. I am of Norwegian descent...people who arrived to a hardscrabble existence in the 1880s north of Dodge City, Kansas and survived. Different story than yours but the determination was the same.

Thank you for writing about your father. It helps us all to reach out to immigrants who want a better life for themselves and their families. God bless America!

Thank you for your eloquent tribute to your father's memory at this time of  loss and sadness. I found that with time the feeling of fatherlessness  was replaced by the memories that keep him present within.
You stated that your father was an Armenian but his name is anything but Armenian. How come?

Dear Mr. Kristof,
Thank you for your fine tribute to your father. You and he were both lucky men. It is very apparent that his spirit will be carried on in your own good work. I congratulate you both.
Hugh Kelleher
Newburyport, MA

Your father would be proud.  We all must do what we can to pass on the legacy of your father's generation:  be fundamentally optimistic, be principled, and be dogged in the pursuit of what is good and right.  Bravo to you and your father.

Nicholas,

This is a wonderful tribute to the legacy of your father's life and story. Thank you for sharing it with us. My hope is that in writing it you found solace in your loss.

Your life and life's work is a living tribute to the heroic life your father led. The people you are helping with your courage, talent and heart is an extension of your father's legacy. Please accept my sympathy to you, your mother and family at your father's death.

Nicholas,
So sorry for your loss. Your father sound like he was a great guy, and surely a tremendous inspiration to you and many others. May he rest well. He had a full life!! Heartfelt condolences to your entire family.

Mr. Kristof,

I offer sincere condolences to you today.

Like your father, I am a Reed College graduate who went on to breed lilies on the west flank of Mt. Hood and then worked my way toward a graduate degree in pomology at Cornell.

At the age of 50 I am blessed with both my father and my grandfather now 98 years old and lucid if very fragile.

Your column today was a gift.

I wish you and yours peace and the comfort of loving memories.

Few people know of the fabulous place known as the Bukowina. Until the breakup of the Austro-Hungarian Monarchy and the subsequent riving off from Romania of Northern Bukowina in the course and ending of the Second World War, it was the single most diverse ethnic area in the entire area of mixed populations in East Central Europe. Your father's story is in perfect keeping with the area. Few people know also of the extraordinary presence of Armenians in that region and extending west to Lwow and beyond. But your father's story is not foreign to some of us.
My daughter (Georgetown, RADA & LAMDA in London) has just sent me your column on the occasion of your fatherless Father's Day. She lives in Brooklyn and works on Wall Street and in the theater. She must have seen some resemblance between me and your father despite the fact that I am a WASP, some 300 years resident in North Carolina. My doctorate (Columbia) and my position in retirement as Honorary Consul of the Republic of Poland in Raleigh have given me an appreciation of the area and its peoples. My mere 6,000 or so books in the languages necessary for the area may have played a role. I have spoken locally at funerals of men who were in Norilsk and got out on the last boat before winter by the skin of their sheer good fortune to join the Anders' Army; men who were not quite so lucky and had to settle for the next best thing: joining General Berling's group; men who were never in the Soviet camps but got to Palestine by heading southeast on foot to get to neutral Turkey; men who happened not to be at home at the end of 1940 when their homes were raided and their families carted off to Siberia and who then survived from the age of 15 by their wits; men who in the 1980s received letters from half-brothers and half-sisters outside Vladisvostok and learned that their fathers had survived and started over with what they might be able to muster; men who . . . men who . . . women who . . . .
My daughter knows me well in sending me your memories. Thank you for them.
Mark Fountain
Dr. Alvin M. Fountain II

Nicholas:

You Dad led a remarkable life and produced wonderful offsprings. I KNOW you are very proud of him.

May his rest in peace!

Thank you for such a touching column.  I gained strength and optimism from your father's story.  His unrelentless spirit is very present in the story.  I work as a pcp in MA and meet troubled young people everyday.  I always question where their spirit and instinct for survival are ? Your father went through so much and never bowed down to concepts of fate, destiny, and managed to come out of that situation with still hope for the future.  I am sorry for your loss and I believe his spirit in within you.

I have long respected the work you have done regarding women, peace, and international relations.  Now I can see how you became such a wonderful person.  Thank you for sharing these thoughts with the world.  There are always regrets, but I am sure your father knew what a fine son he had.   We can never lose our fathers, you will always carry yours, in your spirit of justice and peace.
Well said.  My first fatherless Father's Day. He was 93.  I still have my mom.  They were married 64 years.  I hit the Super-Lotto in terms of parents too.
